poem:
### Bagdad

Five minutes in,  
soft slurry of sand   
sweeps across cracked   
pavement –  
a ghost town's hum.  
  
In the heat,  
the tiny cafe awakens;   
faces, sun-scorched,  
enter with quiet hope,  
  
reaching for a past  
unplucked,  
waiting for revival  
behind the diner's door—  
a cup,   
steaming.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A Route 66 ghost town was ‘frozen in time’. Is it on the brink of a comeback? The tiny desert cafe, caught in a desolate middle between Los Angeles and Las Vegas, had only been open for five minutes when the first customers of the day ambled in from the already blistering heat. It was a Friday morning in June, sand swirling outside across the cracked street and towards the Bagdad Cafe’s front door. In". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
